{{Short description|School of theology}} {{Feminism sidebar|religious variants}} {{Christianity|expanded=hide}}
'''Christian feminism''' is a school of [[Christian theology]] which uses the viewpoint of a Christian to promote and understand morally, socially, and spiritually the [[Gender equality|equality]] of men and women.<ref name=":422">{{Cite journal |last=Hassey |first=Janette |date=1989 |title=A Brief History of Christian Feminism |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/026537888900600201 |journal=Transformation: An International Journal of Holistic Mission Studies |language=en |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=1–5 |doi=10.1177/026537888900600201 |issn=0265-3788}}</ref> Christian [[Theology|theologians]] argue that contributions by women and acknowledging women's value are necessary for a complete understanding of [[Christianity]]. Christian feminists are driven by the belief that God does not discriminate on the basis of biologically determined characteristics such as sex and race, but created all humans to exist in harmony and equality regardless of those factors.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=McPhillips |first=Kathleen |date=1999 |title=Theme: Feminisms, Religions, Cultures, Identities |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/08164649993083 |journal=Australian Feminist Studies |volume=14 |issue=30 |pages=255–258 |doi=10.1080/08164649993083 |issn=0816-4649}}</ref> On the other hand, [[Christian egalitarianism]] is used for those advocating gender equality and equity among Christians but do not wish to associate themselves with the feminist movement.
Christian feminists and scholars believe that interpretations of biblical texts as well as works of some religious figures may push sexist traits or responsibilities that if they are not acknowledged, may continue to perpetuate the patriarchy present in the church. The issues that arise from the patriarchy in the church include the discouraged ordination of women, the lack of equality in a [[marriage]], [[Abortion-rights movements|abortion rights]], the lack of recognition for women's [[spirituality]], and pushing a masculine image of [[God]].<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Daggers |first=Jenny |date=2001 |title='Working for Change in the Position of Women in the Church': Christian Women's Information and Resources (CWIRES) and the British Christian Women's Movement, 1972-1990 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/096673500100002604 |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=9 |issue=26 |pages=44–69 |doi=10.1177/096673500100002604 |issn=0966-7350}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=McEwan |first=Dorothea |date=1999 |title=The Future of Christian Feminist Theologies—As I Sense it: Musings on the Effects of Historiography and Space |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/096673509900002206 |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=8 |issue=22 |pages=79–92 |doi=10.1177/096673509900002206 |issn=0966-7350}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Mclntosh |first=Esther |date=2007 |title=The Possibility of a Gender-Transcendent God: Taking Macmurray Forward |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0966735007072034 |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=236–255 |doi=10.1177/0966735007072034 |issn=0966-7350}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal |last=Polinska |first=Wioleta |date=2004 |title=In Woman's Image: An Iconography for God |url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/096673500401300104 |journal=Feminist Theology |language=en |volume=13 |issue=1 |pages=40–61 |doi=10.1177/096673500401300104 |issn=0966-7350}}</ref> Concerns also exist over how women are handled in today's culture since they are expected to be subordinate to men, according to how early Christian religious writings are interpreted.<ref name=":622">{{Cite journal |last=Beecheno |first=Kim |date=2021-11-22 |title=Conservative Christianity and Intimate Partner Violence in Brazil |journal=Religion and Gender |volume=11 |issue=2 |pages=245–264 |doi=10.1163/18785417-bja10007 |issn=2589-8051|doi-access=free }}</ref> Despite that, women are continuing to pursue the goodness that the Christian faith teaches them and an example is Japan's [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union]]. Through interpretations of biblical texts and writings of early religious figures, Christian feminists and scholars draw from these sources to argue both [[sexism]] present in Christianity and the equality that should be present between men and women. These texts then present the inconsistencies of concepts that emerge between the writings of religious figures and the Bible.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Clack |first=Beverley |date=1999 |title=Thealogy and Theology: Mutually Exclusive or Creatively Interdependent? |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/096673509900002103 |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=7 |issue=21 |pages=21–38 |doi=10.1177/096673509900002103 |issn=0966-7350}}</ref><ref name=":422"/>
== History ==
Some Christian feminists believe that the principle of egalitarianism was present in the teachings of [[Jesus]] and the early Christian movements such as [[Marianismo]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Universidade Federal da Bahia: Mariana Cardoso Carvalho {{!}} Gênero {{!}} Etnia, raça e gênero|url=https://pt.scribd.com/document/400489853/9-As-Primeiras-Fronteiras-Fernando-Fernandez-e-Bernardo-Araujo|work=Scribd|access-date=2020-01-10|language=pt|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200227164456/https://pt.scribd.com/document/400489853/9-As-Primeiras-Fronteiras-Fernando-Fernandez-e-Bernardo-Araujo|archive-date=2020-02-27|url-status=dead}}</ref> but this is a highly contested view by many feminist scholars who believe that Christianity itself relies heavily on [[gender role]]s.<ref name=":1" /> {{by whom|date=August 2018}} These interpretations of Christian origins have been criticized by [[Secularity|secular]] feminists for "anachronistically projecting contemporary ideals back into the first century."<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 20487897|title = Christian Origins, Egalitarianism, and Utopia|journal = Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion|volume = 23|issue = 2|pages = 27–49|last1 = Beavis|first1 = Mary Ann|year = 2007|doi = 10.2979/FSR.2007.23.2.27| s2cid=144025040 }}</ref> In the [[Middle Ages]] [[Julian of Norwich]] and [[Hildegard of Bingen]] explored the idea of a divine power with both masculine and feminine characteristics.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Bauerschmidt |first=Frederick Christian |title=Seeing Jesus: Julian of Norwich and the Text of Christ's Body |journal=Journal of Medieval and Early Modern Studies |volume=27 |issue=2 |year=1997 |pages=189–214}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1177/096673509900002203| title=Hildegard of Bingen: A Woman for our Time| journal=Feminist Theology| volume=8| issue=22| pages=25–41| year=1999| last1=Boyce-Tillman| first1=June| s2cid=144317390}}</ref> Proto-feminist works from the fifteenth to seventeenth centuries addressed objections to women learning, teaching and preaching in a religious context.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal |last1=McEwan |first1=Dorothea |year=1999 |title=The Future of Christian Feminist Theologies—As I Sense it: Musings on the Effects of Historiography and Space |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=8 |issue=22 |pages=79–92 |doi=10.1177/096673509900002206 |s2cid=144816076}}</ref> One such proto-feminist was [[Anne Hutchinson]] who was cast out of the [[Puritan]] colony of [[Massachusetts]] for teaching on the dignity and rights of women.<ref>{{cite book|isbn=978-0824516796|title=All Saints: Daily Reflections on Saints, Prophets, and Witnesses for Our Time|last1=Ellsberg|first1=Robert|year=1997|publisher=Crossroad Publishing Company |url-access=registration|url=https://archive.org/details/allsaintsdailyre00ells}}</ref>
The [[First-wave feminism|first wave]] of feminism in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries included an increased interest in the place of women in religion.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal |last=Hassey |first=Janette |date=1989 |title=A Brief History of Christian Feminism |journal=Transformation |volume=6 |issue=2 |pages=1–5 |doi=10.1177/026537888900600201 |jstor=43052265 |s2cid=150983833}}</ref> Women who were campaigning for their rights began to question their inferiority both within the church and in other spheres, which had previously been justified by church teachings.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi=10.1177/096673500301200107| title=Imagining God in Our Ways: The Journals of Frances E. Willard| journal=Feminist Theology| volume=12| pages=75–88| year=2003| last1=Capitani| first1=Diane| s2cid=144031930}}</ref> Some Christian feminists of this period were [[Marie Maugeret]], [[Katharine Bushnell]], [[Catherine Booth]], [[Frances Willard (suffragist)|Frances Willard]].
During the 1960s and 1970s many evangelical women were influenced by the [[civil rights movement]].<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Gallagher|first=Sally K.|date=2004|title=The Marginalization of Evangelical Feminism|journal=Sociology of Religion|volume=65|issue=3|pages=215–237|doi=10.2307/3712250|issn=1069-4404|jstor=3712250}}</ref> Christian Feminists began writing and publishing articles concerning reproductive rights as well as inequality in marriage and in the religious hierarchy.<ref name=":1" /> In response to these articles, groups such as the EWC or [[Evangelical Women's Caucus]], and the ESA or [[Evangelicals for Societal Action]] were formed in order to create a social movement in the church to address such issues.<ref name=":1" />
== Issues == {{Christianity and gender|positions}}
=== Women in church leadership === {{main|Ordination of women}}
The division of [[Protestantism|Protestant]] belief systems into different denominations allowed for women to acquire far more leadership positions in the church, as certain denominations then had the freedom to advocate for female leadership.<ref name=":0" /> In both mainline and liberal branches of [[Protestantism|Protestant Christianity]], women are ordained as [[clergy]]. Even some theologically conservative denominations, such as [[The Church of the Nazarene]]<ref>{{cite book |title=Church of the Nazarene Manual |date=2017 |publisher=Nazarene Publishing House |location=Kansas City, MO |isbn=978-0-8341-3711-0 |page=192 |url=http://www.nazarene.org/sites/default/files/docs/GenSec/Manual/2017%20-2021%20Manual |access-date=20 August 2018 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180831220223/http://www.nazarene.org/sites/default/files/docs/GenSec/Manual/2017%20-2021%20Manual |archive-date=31 August 2018 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and [[Assemblies of God]],<ref>{{cite web |date=1990-08-14 |url=http://ag.org/top/beliefs/position_papers/pp_downloads/pp_4191_women_ministry.pdf |title=The Role of Women in Ministry |pages=7 |publisher=The General Council of the Assemblies of God |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20060523225854/http://ag.org/top/beliefs/position_papers/pp_downloads/pp_4191_women_ministry.pdf |archive-date=2006-05-23 |url-status=dead }}</ref> ordain women as pastors. However, the [[Roman Catholic Church]], the [[Eastern Orthodox Church]], the [[Southern Baptist Convention]] (the largest Protestant denomination in the U.S.),<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.sbc.net/aboutus/pswomen.asp |title=SBC Position Statements - Women in Ministry |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080921171219/http://www.sbc.net/aboutus/pswomen.asp |archive-date=2008-09-21 |url-status=dead }}</ref> as well as [[the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church), and many churches in the American [[Evangelicalism|Evangelical]] movement prohibit women from entering clerical positions.<ref>{{cite journal | url=https://doi.org/10.1007%2FBF02393417 | doi=10.1007/BF02393417 | title=Male god imagery and female submission: Lessons from a southern baptist ladies' bible class | year=1996 | last1=Pevey | first1=Carolyn | last2=Williams | first2=Christine L. | last3=Ellison | first3=Christopher G. | journal=Qualitative Sociology | volume=19 | issue=2 | pages=173–193 | s2cid=144189360 }}</ref> Some Christian feminists believe that as women have greater opportunity to receive theological training, they will have greater influence on how scriptures are interpreted by those that deny women the right to become ministers.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal |last1=Harrison |first1=Victoria S. |year=2007 |title=Modern Women, Traditional Abrahamic Religions and Interpreting Sacred Texts |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=145–159 |doi=10.1177/0966735007072020 |s2cid=145641264}}</ref>
=== Interpretations of gender based scriptures === {{Disputed section|date=October 2018}} {{Religious text primary|section|date=March 2016}} Many of the Christian ideals concerning gender stem from interpretations of the Bible.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Kobes Du Mez|first=Kristin|date=2015|title=A New Gospel for Women: Katherine Bushnell and the Challenge of Christian Feminism|publisher=Oxford University Press|pages=27–28|isbn=978-0190205645}}</ref> Christian feminists have often argued that the Bible is problematic, not because of the text itself, but because of the Christian scholars who have interpreted the scripture throughout time.<ref name=":6" /> An example of these inconsistencies can be found in the [[Creation story in Genesis|creation story]] of Adam and Eve; some Evangelicals believe that Adam and Eve were created at the same time, while others believe that Eve was made from the rib of Adam.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=La Croix|first=Richard R.|date=January 1984|title=The paradox of Eden|journal=International Journal for Philosophy of Religion|volume=15|issue=3|pages=171|doi=10.1007/bf00137064|s2cid=171018210 |issn=0020-7047}}</ref> There is also wide debate within many Christian denominations over the fault of Eve concerning the consumption of the [[forbidden fruit]], and the entrance of sin into the world.<ref name=":3" /> Historically, a great deal of blame has been placed on Eve, but many Christian Feminists have worked to reframe the story, and shift the blame equally between both parties, as both partook of the fruit.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harvey|first=Richard|date=1991|title=Early English Feminism and the Creation Myth|journal=The Historian|volume=54|issue=1|pages=35–48|jstor=24447931|doi=10.1111/j.1540-6563.1991.tb00839.x}}</ref> The story of Adam and Eve is just one example of a text which Christian feminists believe is [[Patriarchy|patriarchal]] in nature due to its interpretation.<ref>{{Cite journal|date=September 1993|title=Redeeming Eve|journal=English Literary Renaissance|volume=23|issue=3|pages=490–508|doi=10.1111/j.1475-6757.1993.tb01071.x|issn=0013-8312|last1= McChrystal|first1= Deirdre Keenan|s2cid=222443144 }}</ref> Some Christian Feminists made the decision to abandon direct scriptural use in their fight for equality, while others relied on verses that opposed patriarchal ideals, pointing out the inconsistencies within the Bible.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal |last=Mohrmann |first=Margaret |date=2015-04-24 |title=Feminist Ethics and Religious Ethics |journal=Journal of Religious Ethics |volume=43 |issue=2 |pages=185–192 |doi=10.1111/jore.12093 |issn=0384-9694}}</ref> The following passages act as examples of these inconsistencies.
* {{Bibleverse|Galatians|3:28}}. "There is neither...male nor female for all are one in Christ Jesus." * [[Deborah]] of the [[Old Testament]] was a [[prophetess]] and "judge of Israel"<ref>[http://www.amit.org.il/learning/english/JW/Deborah.htm Deborah the Prophetess] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071219100012/http://www.amit.org.il/learning/english/JW/Deborah.htm |date=2007-12-19 }}</ref> * {{Bibleverse|Genesis|2:20}}. The word translated "help" or "helper" is the same Hebrew word, "ēzer," which the Old Testament uses more than 17 times to describe the kind of help that God brings to His people in times of need; e.g., "Thou art my help (ēzer) and my deliverer," and "My help ''(ēzer)'' comes from the Lord." Never once in all these references is the word used to indicate subordination or servitude to another human being.<ref>[http://www.godswordtowomen.org/ezerkenegdo.htm "Ezer Kenegdo" Word Study. God's Word to Women, 2011]</ref> * {{Bibleverse|Genesis|3:16}}. "To the woman he (God) said, 'I will greatly increase your pains in childbearing; in pain you shall bring forth children, yet your desire shall be for your husband, and he shall rule over you.{{' "}} * {{Bibleverse|1 Timothy|2:12}}. "But I suffer not a woman to teach, nor to usurp authority over the man, but to be in silence." * {{Bibleverse|1 Corinthians|11:7-9}}. "For a man ought not to cover his head, since he is the image and glory of God, but woman is the glory of man. For man was not made from woman, but woman from man. Neither was man created for woman, but woman for man." * {{Bibleverse|1 Corinthians|14:34}}. "The women should keep silent in the churches. For they are not permitted to speak, but should be in submission, as the Law also says." * {{Bibleverse|Colossians|3:18}}. "Wives, submit to your husbands, as is fitting in the Lord." * {{Bibleverse|1 Peter|3:1}}. "Likewise, wives, be subject to your own husbands, so that even if some do not obey the word, they may be won without a word by the conduct of their wives." * {{bibleverse|Ephesians|5:22-24}}. "Wives, be subject to your husbands as you are to the Lord. For the husband is the head of the wife just as Christ is the head of the church, the body of which he is the Savior. Just as the church is subject to Christ, so also wives ought to be, in everything, to their husbands." Translations of [[Biblical canon|biblical scriptures]] are examples where social hierarchy may influence the actual meaning of biblical scriptures. Although the pronoun ''him'' is often used in the scripture, [[Robert Alter]], a Hebrew professor, argues that it is not "anatomically masculine."<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal |last1=Nicholson |first1=Sarah |last2=Domoney-Lyttle |first2=Zanne |date=2020-01-01 |title=Women and Gender in the Bible and the Biblical World: Editorial Introduction |journal=Open Theology |language=en |volume=6 |issue=1 |pages=706–710 |doi=10.1515/opth-2020-0143 |issn=2300-6579|doi-access=free }}</ref> These variations in pronouns may lead to exacerbating the division between [[Sexism|feminine and masculine roles]] and encourage the gender hierarchy. Furthermore, the separation between male and female is implied not only by the use of gendered pronouns, but also by the absence of representation of women and gendering qualities and tasks. [[Augustine of Hippo|Saint Augustine]], a bishop of Hippo, wrote a tractate on John's Gospel and in the section about the Wisdom of God, he does not mention any female figure or femininity that the [[Old Testament]] regards within [[Wisdom literature]].<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal |last1=Conway |first1=Colleen M. |last2=Jasper |first2=Alison |date=2001 |title=The Shining Garment of the Text: Gendered Readings of John's Prologue |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.2307/3268319 |journal=Journal of Biblical Literature |volume=120 |issue=2 |pages=383 |doi=10.2307/3268319 |jstor=3268319 |issn=0021-9231}}</ref> While it is unclear the reason behind the absence of women being mentioned in Saint Augustine's tractates, modern scholars argue that this information is too crucial in understanding the Wisdom in the Old Testament to be omitted.<ref name=":22" /> [[File:Salomon Koninck - David and Batsheba Mourning over Their Dead Son - WGA12248.jpg|thumb|Painting depicting Bathsheba and David mourning the death of their son, Nathan.]]
On the other hand, by designating qualities to either be feminine or masculine, it creates expectations of how men and women must act. In the [[Books of Kings|Book of Kings]], they emphasize the role of mothers by the grief that they must display towards the death of their family members. Thus, even in royalty, the role of a mother is valued over queenship. For instance, in Samuel 2, when [[Bathsheba]] mourned the death of her son, she establishes her role as a mother. Then, as there are specific traits that are expected of women, if they fail to meet these qualities, then they are characterized as masculine.<ref name=":02" /> Contrasting Bathsheba's display of her maternal role is [[Athaliah|Athaliah's]] massacre of the royals of Judah that led her to become the monarch for several years. Caused by her ruthlessness and headstrong personality, Athaliah is often described to display masculinity but also described as not being entirely masculine because of her identity as a woman.<ref name=":02" />
=== Sexuality and reproductive rights === {{See also|Christianity and abortion}}
In general, many Christian feminist scholars argue that they envision a society in which female sexuality is not condemned by the church but acknowledged as a natural part of human existence.<ref name=":5">{{cite book |last=Nove |first=Alec |title=Studies in Economics and Russia |date=1990 |publisher=Palgrave Macmillan UK |isbn=9781349109937 |pages=153–163 |chapter=Friedman, Markets and Planning: A Comment |doi=10.1007/978-1-349-10991-3_12}}</ref>{{Failed verification|date=November 2023}} During the [[Reformation]], theologians such as [[Martin Luther]] and [[John Calvin]] stressed the importance of [[chastity]] and marriage, leading to further repression of female sexuality within the Christian tradition.<ref>{{Cite book |last=Radford Ruether |first=Rosemary |title=Introducing Redemption in Christian Feminism |publisher=Sheffield Academic Press |year=1998 |isbn=978-1-85075-888-4 |location=Sheffield, England |pages=13–14}}</ref> Many Christian feminists have stated that men in powerful religious positions have often used the scriptures, and teachings from theologians such as Calvin and Luther to both dominate and repress women's sexuality, a problem which Christian feminists believe needs to be solved immediately.<ref name=":5" />{{Failed verification|date=November 2023}}
Conservative religious groups are often in conflict with feminist and liberal religious groups over [[abortion]] and the use of [[birth control]]. Scholars like sociologist Flann Campbell have argued that conservative religious denominations tend to restrict [[Human male sexuality|male]] and [[Human female sexuality|female]] sexuality<ref>{{cite journal |title = Birth Control and the Christian Churches |last = Campbell |first = Flann |journal = [[Population Studies]] |issn = 0032-4728 |volume = 14 |issue = 2 |year = 1960 |pages = 131–47 |doi = 10.2307/2172010 |jstor = 2172010 }}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=yUWz24sVu54C&pg=PP13 Ordaining Women: Culture and Conflict in Religious Organizations]</ref> by prohibiting or limiting birth control use<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://www.vatican.va/holy_father/paul_vi/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-vi_enc_25071968_humanae-vitae_en.html |title=Paul VI - Humanae Vitae<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070811095540/https://www.vatican.va/holy_father/paul_vi/encyclicals/documents/hf_p-vi_enc_25071968_humanae-vitae_en.html |archive-date=2007-08-11 |url-status=dead }}</ref> and condemning abortion as [[sin]]ful [[murder]].<ref>[http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/baptist/sbcabres.html Southern Baptist Convention Resolutions on Abortion<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref><ref>[http://www.bible-knowledge.com/Sin-of-Abortion.html Sin of Abortion and the Reasons Why<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070806191124/http://www.bible-knowledge.com/Sin-of-Abortion.html|date=2007-08-06}}</ref> Some Christian feminists (like [[Teresa Forcades]]) contend that a woman's "right to control her pregnancy is bounded by considerations of her own well-being" and that restricted access to birth control and abortion disrespects her God-given [[choice|free will]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500100002807|title = Revisioning Christ|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 10|issue = 28|pages = 82–92|year = 2001|last1 = Kim|first1 = Grace Ji-Sun| s2cid=220706278 }}</ref>
Philosophy scholars Bruce P. Blackshaw and Nicholas Colgrove, along with health professional Daniel Rodger, argue that [[Anti-abortion movements|anti-abortion]] arguments are often inconsistent.<ref name=":52">{{Cite journal |last1=Blackshaw |first1=Bruce P. |last2=Colgrove |first2=Nicholas |last3=Rodger |first3=Daniel |date=2022-04-03 |title=Why inconsistency arguments fail: a response to Shaw |journal=The New Bioethics |volume=28 |issue=2 |pages=139–151 |doi=10.1080/20502877.2022.2070960 |issn=2050-2877|doi-access=free |pmid=35531764 }}</ref> The researchers find that anti-abortion activists often use [[Faulty generalization|overgeneralization]] in their arguments, causing them to believe that their belief applies to all women regardless of varying priorities, virtues, and beliefs. Moreover, they emphasize the importance of listening to various perspectives in especially in a topic such as abortion where these choices are made on a case-by-case basis. In addition, there may also be inconsistencies in the reasoning of pro-life activists as to why abortion is immoral. For instance, some may utilize Don Marquis' term, the "future of value," which entails assuming that the embryo will have potential contributions to society if carried until birth.<ref name=":52" />
A number of socially [[Christian left|progressive]] mainline Protestant denominations as well as certain Jewish organizations and the group [[Catholics for Choice|Catholics for a Free Choice]] have formed the [[Religious Coalition for Reproductive Choice]].<ref>[http://www.rcrc.org/about/members.cfm RCRC—Member Organizations<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070316134019/http://www.rcrc.org/about/members.cfm|date=2007-03-16}}</ref> The RCRC often works as a liberal feminist organization and in conjunction with other American feminist groups to oppose conservative religious denominations which, from their perspective, seek to suppress the natural reproductive rights of women.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://www.nwlc.org/details.cfm?id=1223&section=Reproductive%20Rights%3A%20General%20Materials |title=National Women's Law Center<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=2007-08-12 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070715033831/https://www.nwlc.org/details.cfm?id=1223&section=Reproductive%20Rights%3A%20General%20Materials |archive-date=2007-07-15 |url-status=dead }}</ref>
[[File:The birth of Christ; female angels swoon through the air; Jo Wellcome V0034607.jpg|thumb|Female Centered Depiction of the Birth of Christ]]
=== Feminine or gender-transcendent God ===
{{see also|Gender of God}}
Some Christian feminists believe that gender equality within the church cannot be achieved without rethinking the portrayal and understanding of [[God]] as a [[masculinity|masculine]] being.<ref name=":4" /> The theological concept of [[Sophia (wisdom)|Sophia]], usually seen as replacing or synonymous with the [[Holy Spirit]] in the [[Trinity]], is often used to fulfill this desire for symbols which reflect women's religious experiences.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Ignatian Spirituality and Christian Feminism|last=McCoy|first=Maria|year=2015|pages=99–100}}</ref> How Sophia is configured is not static, but usually filled with emotions and individual expression.<ref name=":7" /> For some Christian feminists, the Sophia concept is found in a search for women who reflect contemporary feminist ideals in both the Old and New Testament. Some figures used for this purpose include the [[Virgin Mary]], [[Mary Magdalene]],<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/096673500200002903|title = Go Tell! Thinking About Mary Magdalene|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 10|issue = 29|pages = 19–31|year = 2002|last1 = Winkett|first1 = Lucy| s2cid=170272653 }}</ref> [[Eve]],<ref>{{Cite journal |doi = 10.1177/0966735006068860|title = Book Review: The British Christian Women's Movement: A Rehabilitation of Eve|journal = Feminist Theology|volume = 15|pages = 128–129|year = 2006|last1 = Isherwood|first1 = isa| s2cid=144892324 }}</ref> and [[Esther]].<ref>{{Cite journal |jstor = 20487926|title = Reclaiming the Hebrew Bible for Women: The Neoliberal Turn in Contemporary Feminist Scholarship|journal = Journal of Feminist Studies in Religion|volume = 24|issue = 2|pages = 45–65|last1 = Fuchs|first1 = Esther|year = 2008|doi = 10.2979/FSR.2008.24.2.45| s2cid=145277557 }}</ref> Others see God as entirely gender-transcendent,<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal |last1=McLntosh |first1=Esther |year=2007 |title=The Possibility of a Gender-Transcendent God: Taking Macmurray Forward |journal=Feminist Theology |volume=15 |issue=2 |pages=236–255 |doi=10.1177/0966735007072034 |s2cid=145121811}}</ref> or focus on the feminine aspects of God and [[Jesus]].<ref name=":4" /> A female depiction of the Christ figure, known as Christa, recently arose in an attempt to allow for the power of the Christ figure to be applied to both the masculine and the feminine.<ref name=":5" />{{Failed verification|date=November 2023}} Some Christian feminists use and promote gender-neutral or feminine language and imagery to describe God or Christ. Christian Feminists also call for a gender neutral reading of the Bible, as male pronouns are heavily used as compared to female pronouns throughout the text.<ref>{{cite book|last=Kurian|first=George Thomas|chapter=Women and Theology|date=2011-11-25|publisher=Blackwell Publishing Ltd|isbn=9781405157629|doi=10.1002/9780470670606.wbecc1601|title=The Encyclopedia of Christian Civilization}}</ref> The [[United Church of Christ]] describes its [[New Century Hymnal]], published in 1995, as "the only hymnal released by a Christian church that honors in equal measure both male and female images of God."<ref>{{Cite web | url=http://www.ucc.org/about-us/old-firsts.html | title=UCC 'Firsts' | access-date=2012-12-07 | archive-date=2017-11-15 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171115110128/http://www.ucc.org/about-us/old-firsts.html | url-status=dead }}</ref>
== Women and their roles in Christianity == The following are a few translations of Greek Christian texts and biblical texts that show the roles that women partook in the Christianity and their actions that exemplify a follower of God.
* [[Mary, mother of Jesus|Mary]], the mother of [[Jesus]], is a prominent example of the significance of women in Christianity. When she was approached by Gabriel the archangel, she has shown her devotion to God by accepting His summoning to become the mother of Jesus Christ, the Savior.<ref name=":32">{{Cite journal |last=C. Phan |first=Peter |date=2016-06-07 |title=Saint and Sinner: Women in Christianity |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.5339/rels.2016.women.13 |journal=Religions: A Scholarly Journal |volume=2016 |issue=1 |doi=10.5339/rels.2016.women.13 |issn=2218-7480}}</ref> * In Ecclesiastical History 5.1.3-54, [[Blandina]] who was tortured remained strong despite the pain as she was guided by God's glory. She proclaims, "I am a Christian; we do nothing to be ashamed of," regardless of the sufferings she went through for being Christian.<ref name=":12">{{Cite book |title=Women in early Christianity: translations from Greek texts |date=2005 |publisher=Catholic University of America Press |isbn=978-0-8132-1417-7 |editor-last=Miller |editor-first=Patricia Cox |location=Washington, D.C.}}</ref> * The section in Gerontius, ''Life of [[Melania the Younger]]'' 42-48 is about [[Melania the Younger|Melania's]] attempt to teach women the virtues of a Christian woman to fully serve Jesus Christ. She taught the importance of never being distracted by temptation and to dutifully follow the teachings of the Psalm. Furthermore, Melania inspires her fellow women to unwaveringly devote themselves to God and fight for their faiths.<ref name=":12" /> [[File:The Bible panorama, or The Holy Scriptures in picture and story (1891) (14598328380).jpg|thumb|Depiction of the poor widow offering coins to the temple treasury which displays her trust in God.]] * [[Paula of Rome]] is another female figure that has traits that are often ascribed to men by her being wealthy and influential. Like Melania the Younger, she lived the [[Gospel]] by opening monasteries for women and devoted herself to helping the less fortunate.<ref name=":32" /> * In Mark 12:41-44, [[Jesus]] witnessed a poor widow offering two copper coins to a temple, and he declared, "Truly I tell you, this poor widow has put in more than all those who are contributing to the treasury. For all of them have contributed out of their abundance; but she out of her poverty has put in everything she had, all she had to live on."<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Almirzanah |first=Syafa’atun |date=2022-12-20 |title=Following the model of Jesus: Rethinking women discipleship in Catholic tradition |url=http://www.hts.org.za/index.php/HTS/article/view/7860 |journal=HTS Teologiese Studies / Theological Studies |language=en |volume=78 |issue=1 |doi=10.4102/hts.v78i1.7860 |issn=2072-8050|doi-access=free |hdl=2263/91834 |hdl-access=free }}</ref>
== Contemporary Christian perspectives on women == In addition to learning the importance of women in Christianity through biblical texts, learning also about how Christianity affects women in the contemporary timeframe is crucial. This section demonstrates how the [[patriarchy]] interwoven into Christianity remains harmful to women even in contemporary society, whereas when Christianity is applied without implying the submission of women, it allows women to be able to fully participate in the religion.
In a research determining the effect of Christianity on [[Domestic violence|domestically abused]] women, more complications arise in São Paulo, Brazil, in dealing with domestic violence when these situations are dealt by people influenced by the patriarchy that has woven its way into Christianity. In addition, these women are also troubled by the abuse they have experienced due to the teachings of the Christian faith. For instance, a woman, Adriana, said that despite being abused by her husband who is a policeman, she felt unable to leave her husband as she believed that her marriage was blessed by God. Upon admitting her situation to a pastor and his wife, they told her that fervent prayer will answer her troubles. To change Adriana's perspective, Edna, a psychologist and a woman who also grew up in a [[Pentecostalism|Pentecostal]] culture, helped Adriana navigate her husband's abuse and her faith. By doing so she allows Adriana as well as other women she has helped to reflect on whether the violence that they are receiving from their husbands is a situation that God would want them to remain in. In addition, there are religious figures such as pastors and priests that have told these abused women that their belief in God will bring change. Sometimes, these women are told that their abuse is caused by their own inadequacies.<ref name=":622"/>
On the other hand, amidst the patriarchal history of Japan, Japanese women who have been politically involved by demanding equal treatment congregated and founded the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union]] which allowed them to support one another and flourish in their careers. A notable member of the organization is Ushioda Chiseko, a charity activist whose altruistic pursuits were driven by her Christian faith. Her contributions include advocating the role of women socially and politically and helped impoverished women gain vocational skills. Another notable member of the organization is [[Hani Motoko]], who is known as the first female journalist in Japan. Through her participation in the [[Woman's Christian Temperance Union|WCTU]], the organization helped Motoko gain attention to her works. Motoko's devotion to Christianity began when she enrolled in a Christian school. Later in her career as a writer, she wrote of a Christian orphanage that informed readers about how to help orphans have more resources and facilities through donations. Motoko also later established household reforms which promote that both men and women should share responsibilities in a home.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Seto |first=Tomoko |date=2017-02-02 |title='Organizing' Meiji Women: the role of the Japanese chapter of the Woman's Christian Temperance Union for individual activists, 1900–1905 |url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/09612025.2017.1280908 |journal=Women's History Review |volume=26 |issue=6 |pages=975–993 |doi=10.1080/09612025.2017.1280908 |issn=0961-2025}}</ref>
The articles mentioned above give insights both about how women show their devotion through Christianity and its impact on their lives and also how women are treated by people of the faith. As these accounts only focus on certain groups of Christianity, they should not be treated as though they reflect all contemporary women's experience in Christianity. {{Further|topic=the South Korean politician and feminist, labor right activist, and Christian feminism activist|Lee Wu-jong}}

== Critiques of Christian feminism ==
=== Roman Catholicism === There have been multiple Popes, like Pope [[John Paul II]] and [[Pope Francis]], who have referenced a type of Feminism in their addresses to the public. Pope Francis is quoted saying the "irreplaceable role of the woman in the family ... [t]he gifts of -delicacy ... which are a richness of the feminine spirit, represent a genuine force for the life of the family ... without which the human vocation would be unrealizable."<ref>{{Cite web|title=IN HIS THOUGHTS AND IN HIS WORDS: FRANCIS ON WOMEN by MIRIAM DUIGNAN|url=http://womensordinationcampaign.org/articles/2016/2/4/in-his-thoughts-and-in-his-words-francis-on-women-by-miriam-duignan|access-date=2020-10-11|website=Women's Ordination Worldwide|language=en-US}}</ref> Some men and women took Pope Francis words as a "vivid hope" that women will take a more prominent role in the Catholic Church.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2014-01-25|title=Pope wants 'capillary and incisive' role for women in church|url=https://www.ncronline.org/blogs/francis-chronicles/pope-wants-capillary-and-incisive-role-women-church|access-date=2020-10-11|website=National Catholic Reporter|language=en}}</ref> These same women and men also believe that "Radical Feminism" is the cause for the teachings of then Pope John Paul II to be viewed as negative, they also believe that Pope John Paul II was taking great strides, at least for his time, to include women in the church.<ref>{{Cite web|title=A Pro-Woman Pope|url=https://www.catholiceducation.org/en/controversy/feminism/a-pro-woman-pope.html|access-date=2020-10-11|website=www.catholiceducation.org|date=15 January 2007 |language=en-gb}}</ref> 20th century figures like [[Dorothy Day]] and [[Mother Teresa]] show the diversity of possibilities for women in modern Catholic community.
===Eastern Orthodox=== Another branch of Christianity that tends to be conservative on the role of women, especially women's ordination, is [[Eastern Orthodoxy]].
===Southern Baptist=== The [[Southern Baptist]] denomination has largely taken a complementarian position on women in recent years.
